Award.AbstractNarration:
Oregon State University proposes to support technical services on R/V Oceanus, a 177? general purpose research vessel as part of the US Academic Fleet scheduled by University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). The vessel is owned by the National Science Foundation. The proposal requests support for both basic and specialized services. For basic services, they will provide one or two shipboard technicians on each cruise of R/V Oceanus to support seagoing research projects and to maintain, calibrate and provide for qualified users items from their pool of shared-use research instrumentation. As part of specialized services, they will continue to operate and maintain the NORCOR facility, a shared use coring facility available to all operators. The SWAP program, which was previously funded under this program as a specialized service will be discontinued. Budget constraints have made it impossible for the Program to continue to support this endeavor. It will be supported, to the extent possible, through basic services. The budget included with this report is for the first year of a 5-year continuing grant.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The support of maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The OSU Marine Technician Group has provided quality support of all science cruies and oceanographic technical systems onbaord the research vessel Oceanus during the life of this award. Below is a summary of the services provided. 
1. Provide technical services at sea in support of all NSF and non-NSF sponsored research aboard R/V OCEANUS.

2. At sea, function as the primary liaison between the R/V OCEANUS crew and the science party.

3. Maintain, repair and calibrate NSF-supported shared-use equipment and instrumentation, and assist in its shipboard use.

4. Provide pre-cruise and post-cruise assistance to scientific parties for cruises aboard the R/V OCEANUS.

5. Provide shore support for NSF-funded shared-use equipment.

6. Provide support for NSF-Funded Specialized Instrumentation Facilities.

7. Provide for the management of data from shared use instrumentation including distribution and transfer of data to the R2R gateway.

8. Provide at sea management of satellite communication systems aboard the R/V Oceanus.

 

The Marine Technician Superintendent manages the OSU Marine Technician Group, shipboard technical services and common-use equipment, including advance scheduling and management of the common-use equipment pool. Members of the Marine Technician Group include three Specialists -2 Marine Tech’s. Additionally, the OSU Marine Technician Group periodically contracts Marine Technicians from the UNOLS Tech Pool. This team has specific duties associated with computer support, instrumentation support, electronics support, and general Marine Technician responsibilities. All members of the OSU Marine Technician Group support science cruises by sailing as the Marine Technician, participating in pre/post cruise logistics, overseeing mobilization/demobilization efforts and maintaining the routine shore-side tasks while not at sea. Each Marine Technician is carefully assigned to support specific cruises that require assistance from their unique area of expertise. The Ship Operations Committee advises the Dean on policy matters in coordination with the Marine Superintendent and Marine Technician Superintendent. OSU Marine Technicians sail in support of science on every R/V Oceanus cruise. The Marine Technician serves as the liaison between the sea going scientific party and the ship’s crew. On cruises where an unusually high level of technical service is required, additional Marine Technicians may be assigned. In some cases, projects requesting additional technical support may cover the extra costs.


Last Modified: 09/25/2018
Modified by: Andrew W Woogen
